pageData.text: In this experiment, students will create various circuits and take measurements to prove <button class='glossary-text'>Ohm’s law</button>.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Digital camera or mobile device capable of taking photos

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Activity 1: Exploring Ohm’s Law
                 Resistors – 20 minutes 
                 Voltage Drop – 30 minutes 
                 Kirchhoff’s Equations – 40 minutes

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: Newton’s Laws of Motion

text: Use <button class='glossary-text'>Ohm’s law</button> to explore the relationships between <button class='glossary-text'>current</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>resistance</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>potential</button> differences in an electric circuit.
Determine currents in loops using Kirchhoff’s laws.
Using the scientific method, demonstrate an understanding of circuits by collecting and analyzing data, drawing conclusions, and documenting results.

pageData.text: Have you ever touched a door handle or shaken someone’s hand and felt an electrical shock? These types of shocks occur because electrons are passed from the object to your hand. These types of shocks are minor and do not generally result in significant injury. Major shocks, however, are responsible for approximately 1,000 deaths every year in the United States. Of these deaths, approximately 400 are due to high-voltage electrical injuries; lightning strikes cause 50 to 300 of these events and 20% of all electrical injuries occur in children<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>.

Low-frequency AC causes prolonged muscle contraction, known as tetany. This contraction makes it difficult for a person being shocked to let go of the source, thus prolonging the length of exposure and potentially increasing the tissue damage. In contrast, DC only causes a single contraction and often propels the person away from the current’s source. As a result, electrical injuries caused by low-frequency AC are three to five times more damaging than DC of equal voltage and current1.

1 Zemaitis, M.R., Foris, L.A., Lopez, R.A., et al. (9 September 2022). Electrical Injuries. StatPearls..
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448087/

pageData.altText: A bolt of lightening in a dark sky.

pageData.text: Electrical circuits are closed-loop devices with an , and electronic components and electronic components (i.e., , , , motors) to perform some task. Typically, either a battery or a power supply provides the circuit with the emf to generate in the circuit. The , V, is measured in terms of volts, defined as 1 Joule/coulomb. Current, I, is the magnitude of the moving charge carriers in a circuit. Current is measured in the unit ampères, A, which is defined as one coulomb of charge passing a single point in one second (1 C/s). To put this into perspective, electrons have a charge of –1.6 x 10–19C, so this would represent 6.25 x 1018 electrons passing a point in one second.

, R, is a material’s opposition to the movement of charge carriers. All matter has some resistance to electrical flow measured in terms of the ohm, Ω, which is defined as 1V/A. There are specific electronic devices that are used to reduce voltage in a circuit by converting the electronic energy to heat. These are called resistors. There are various types of resistor construction, but the ones used in this experiment are called composition resistors because of their construction. The wire leads enter into the resistor and terminate at a composite material. The composite material is a mixture of carbon dust and ceramic powders. The percentage of the ceramic dust in the resistor determines the resistance of the device. Ceramic is an insulator, impeding the charge carriers to traverse the material from carbon atom to carbon atom. A cross section of a composition resistor looks like Figure 1.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: a cross section of a composition resistor, labeling the ceramic core, carbon film, nickel cap, lead, and protective lacquer

pageData.text: To label the <button class='glossary-text'>resistance</button> of the <button class='glossary-text'>resistor</button>, the resistor has colored bands printed on it (see Figure 2).

pageData.altText: Figure 2: from left to right, the brown, gray, red and silverr bands stamped on a resistor

pageData.text: The 4 bands, ABCD, provide the resistance in a scientific notation style: AB × 10C ± D Ω. The first three values are determined by these colors: black = 0, brown = 1, red = 2, orange = 3, yellow = 4, green = 5, blue = 6, violet = 7, gray = 8, and white = 9. The fourth band, or tolerance, is either gold, ± 5%, or silver, ±10%.
Equation 1 represents the relationship between V, I, and R, also known as .

pageData.altText: Equation 1: V equals I times R

pageData.text: Sometimes circuits are more complex and cannot be readily solved by Ohm’s law. For these, we can use . The law states that the total charge entering a circuit junction is equal to the charge leaving that junction. For the junction in Figure 3, with two entering currents (I1 and I2) and two exiting currents (I3 and I4), we can apply the current law.

pageData.altText: Equation 2: begin equation I sub 1 plus I sub 2 equals I sub 3 plus I sub 4 end equation. Begin equation I sub 1 plus I sub 2 minus I  sub 3 minus I sub 4 equals zero end equation.
Figure 3: a junction with four currents: I sub 1 and I sub 2 leading toward the central node and I sub 3 and I sub 4 leading away from the central node

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Kirchhoff’s voltage law</button> states that in a closed loop within a circuit, the total voltage around the loop is equal to the sum of all the voltage drops in that loop. Consider the circuit in Figure 4.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: a circuit with labeled voltage drops at each resistor

pageData.text: Using both laws to solve for a circuit, you must first determine an arbitrary direction for <button class='glossary-text'>current</button> in each loop and branch. For the circuit in Figure 5, the red arrows, representing current, were chosen in the direction of the arrows. Then voltage drops were labeled at each <button class='glossary-text'>resistor</button> based upon the chosen direction of the current. Current entering the resistor is labeled (+) and exiting (–). Finally, the voltage sources are labeled as per their poles in the schematic.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Current loops 1, 2 and 3 with red arrows indicating current and voltage drops based on the current direction

pageData.text: Then apply Kirchhoff’s law to all but one junction. into a junction is positive and current out is negative. In this circuit, there are two junctions, B and E. At junction B, Equation 3 applies.

pageData.altText: Equation 3: I sub 3 minus I sub 2 minus I sub 1 equals zero

pageData.text: Finally, we can solve for the entire circuit. You must choose enough loops that encompass it though. In this case, Loops 1 and 2 suffice. There is a third loop to consider, Loop 3, but Loop 1 and Loop 2 address all parts of the circuit.

Going clockwise in Loop 1 and beginning at point A, we first encounter R1, which has a increase (− to +), so that is +I1 R1. We then encounter the voltage source between B and E, which in this direction goes from + to −, so this is a voltage drop, −V2. Next is R3, also going from − to +, so this potential increase gives, +I1 R3. Finally, we close the loop at V1, which like V2, is also a voltage drop, −V1. Since Kirchhoff’s Law states that all voltage drops must equal zero, Equation 4 applies.

pageData.altText: Equation 4: positive I sub 1 R sub 1 minus V sub 2 plus I sub 1 R sub 3 minus V sub 1 equals zero

pageData.text: Performing the same process around Loop 2, beginning at point B and moving clockwise, we get Equation 5.

pageData.altText: Equation 5: negative I sub 2 R sub 2 minus I sub 2 R sub 4 plus V sub 2 equals zero

pageData.text: Using these three equations and making appropriate substitutions, we can solve for all currents.

imageData.altText: A circuit schematic made up of a loop within a loop. The larger loop has a +5-volt capacitor. The nested loop consists of two parallel 2-ohm resistors.

pageData.question: What is the value of the current that is going through the topmost resistor?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The total resistance of a circuit with resistors in parallel can be calculated by: 1/R = ½ + ½ R = 1 Ω Using Ohm’s law, we have:V = IR(5V) = I(1 Ω)I = 5 A states that the current entering a junction equals the sum of the current leaving the junction. Since both resistors have the same resistance, the current splits equally and we will have 2.5 A through the 2 Ω resistor.

imageData.altText: A circuit schematic made up of a single loop. From the positive end to the negative end of the +20-volt capacitor, the circuit is connected to a 500-ohm resistor and a 100-ohm resistor.

pageData.question: What is the voltage drop across the 500 Ω resistor?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The total resistance of a circuit with resistors in series can be calculated byR = 500 Ω + 100 Ω = 600 ΩUse Ohm’s law to calculate the current of the circuit:V = IR20 V = I(600 Ω)I = 0.03 AUse Ohm’s law again to determine the voltage drop across the 500 Ω resistor:V = IRV = (0.03 A)(500 Ω)V = 16.67 V

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: We can use Ohm’s law to determine the current for the entire circuit, but we must apply Kirchhoff’s current law to determine the amount of current that goes through each resistor.

img.alt: Figure 3: a junction with four currents: I sub 1 and I sub 2 leading toward the central node and I sub 3 and I sub 4 leading away from the central node

hintData.body: We can use Ohm’s law to determine the current for the entire circuit, but we must apply Kirchhoff’s current law to determine the amount of current that goes through each resistor.

pageData.subTitle: Using a Breadboard
pageData.text: The breadboards in your materials kit (see Figure 6) permit you to “build” your circuit without having to permanently attach the components through soldering.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: solderless breadboard

pageData.text: The breadboard has many strips of metal (copper usually) that run underneath the board. The metal strips (yellow lines) are laid out as shown in Figure 7.

pageData.altText: Figure 7: a breadboard with the metal strips in yellow

pageData.text: These strips connect the holes on the top of the board. This makes it easy to connect components together to build circuits. To use the breadboard, the wires of components are placed in the holes (the sockets). The holes are made so that they will hold the component in place. Each hole is connected to one of the metal strips running underneath the board. Basically, those drawn lines over the holes show what holes are connected to one another. Typically, the long rows of holes on the long sides are used for power supply connections. A circuit is built by placing components and connecting them together with wires (your circuit must be a complete loop, with all “lines” connected).

When a path is formed by wires and components from the positive supply node to the negative supply node, we can turn on the power and <button class='glossary-text'>current</button> flows through the path and the circuit works as connected. Figure 8 provides examples of how connections are made to form series and parallel circuits.

pageData.altText: Figure 8: two breadboards: one showing connections made to form a series circuit and the other showing connections to form a parallel circuit

pageData.subTitle: The DMM
pageData.text: The is an indispensable tool in the electronics laboratory for the measurement of voltage, , and current. First, plug the black probe into the COM (common) port of the DMM. That probe will always remain in that port no matter what measurement is being made. To measure voltage, resistance, and very small currents (milliampères), the red probe should be plugged into the port labeled VΩmA. Of course, you will need to turn the dial from the “OFF” setting to the appropriate unit and scale for measure. If your DMM displays the letters OL, you are on the wrong scale; the DMM is measuring higher than that scale will allow. If you need to measure currents larger than 200 mA, you need to plug the red probe into the port labeled 10 ADC (10 ampères max, DC). This port runs the measured current through a fuse, so if the current is too high, the fuse blows instead of the DMM. For measuring voltages and resistances, probe either side of the circuit component(s), or in other words, put the DMM in the circuit in parallel with the voltage or resistance you want to measure (see Figure 9).

pageData.altText: Figure 9: a resistor with back and red arrows on either side showing the digital multimeter is part of the circuit

pageData.text: To measure , the DMM needs to be part of the circuit, connected in series. Break the circuit at the point you wish to measure the current and place the probes on either side of the break (see Figure 10).
That will ensure that the DMM is providing correct measurements. If you connect the DMM to a circuit in parallel while measuring current, you will likely destroy the DMM.

pageData.altText: Figure 10: a resistor with black and red arrows on the right, demonstrating a break in the circuit

A map of the procedural workflow of this investigation. In Activity 1, you will measure the resistance of the resistors. Then, you will build the diagramed circuit and measure the current. Next, you will add additional resistors in series and measure the total resistance and current. Once you have added all of the circuits, you will graph current versus 1 over resistance. Then, you will build the new diagramed circuit, attach the multimeter in series at the specified location and measure the current in the circuit at the given locations.  Next, you will disconnect the multimeter. Once you have tested all of the locations, disconnect the circuit. Then, you will design and build your own circuit with the given parameters. Next, you will draw a schematic of the circuit and photograph it. Then, you will measure the current at the specified locations. Finally, once you have tested both circuits, you will evaluate them using Kirchoff’s equations.

Wear your safety goggles at all times while conducting this investigation. Read all the instructions for the activities before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment.

pageData.altText: goggles symbol

pageData.text: Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this investigation. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after the investigation and clean the work area with soap and water after finishing. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: What is the current of a circuit created with a 5 V emf and a 100 Ω resistor?
Which statement about Kirchhoff’s voltage law is true?

options.text: In a closed loop within a circuit, the total voltage around the loop is equal to the sum of all the voltage drops in that loop.
In a closed loop within a circuit, the total voltage around the loop is equal to zero.
The total charge entering a circuit junction is equal to the charge leaving that junction.
The total charge entering a circuit junction is less than the charge leaving that junction.
The total charge entering a circuit junction is greater than the charge leaving that junction.

assestmentData.question: Which statement about Kirchhoff’s current law is true?

options.text: The total charge entering a circuit junction is equal to the charge leaving that junction.
In a closed loop within a circuit, the total voltage around the loop is equal to the sum of all the voltage drops in that loop.
In a closed loop within a circuit, the total voltage around the loop is equal to zero.
The total charge entering a circuit junction is less than the charge leaving that junction.
The total charge entering a circuit junction is greater than the charge leaving that junction.

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Create a work space.
Read through the activities.
Obtain the required materials.

In Activity 1, you will build circuits, measure their <button class='glossary-text'>resistance</button>, and measure the <button class='glossary-text'>current</button> in the circuit. You will then modify the resistance of the circuits and/or the location of measurement and measure the resulting current. You will also design your own circuits, measure the currents at specified locations and use circuit diagrams and Kirchoff’s equations to evaluate your measurements.
Insert an AA battery (1.5 volts) into the battery cap with bare wire ends.
Choose the with the greatest , measure its resistance, and record the measurement in Data Table 1.
Insert the resistor into the breadboard with each end in different rows, similar to Figure 11.

pageData.altText: Figure 11: a breadboard, showing each end of the resistor in different rows

pageData.text: Create a circuit of the battery and resistor. One of the battery wires should be inserted in the row on one side of the resistor. The other battery wire should be connected in series to one of the DMM probes using alligator clip wires. The other probe of the DMM should be alligator clipped to a wire, which should be inserted into the breadboard at the other side of the resistor (see Figure 12, which has four resistors in parallel, and Figure 13).

pageData.altText: Figure 12: the battery and resistor circuit as described in Step 4
Figure 13: a close view of the breadboard and the placement of the resistors and battery wires

pageData.text: Turn the DMM on, and set it to the 20m setting on DCA, which will measure <button class='glossary-text'>current</button>.

Repeat Steps 2 through 5 for the remaining four resistors, adding each in series and adjusting the circuit appropriately on the breadboard. You may need to move the current scale on the DMM down to the 2000μ scale for adequate precision of measurement as the total resistance increases. Record your measurements for current in Data Table 1.
Graph the data (x = 1/R, y = I ), and plot a linear regression through the points. The slope of this line should be V, the voltage of the battery.
Build the circuit diagrammed in Figure 14 using the breadboard. Figure 15 shows how the circuit should appear.

pageData.altText: Figure 14: schematic of the circuit, with 220 ohms and 330 ohms horizontally at the top, 82 ohms vertically, and 47 ohms and 150 ohms horizontally at the bottom
Figure 15: breadboard with the circuit shown in Figure 14

pageData.text: To this circuit, add 2 AA batteries as shown in Figure 16. Do not insert both wires from each battery into the breadboard at this point.

pageData.altText: Figure 16: the schematic from Figure 14, with plus 1.5 volts added to the right and left side

pageData.text: Insert the red wire from the rightmost battery to the breadboard in the same row as the 150Ω resistor. Using the alligator clipped wires and 1 red wire, connect the DMM to this circuit in series at the point in the circuit highlighted in a red circle (see Figure 17). You will be measuring the current in the left loop.

pageData.altText: Figure 17: Figure 16 schematic with the lower left corner circled in red

pageData.text: This should look like Figure 18. Notice the black DMM probe is clipped to the black wire of the left battery and the red probe of the DMM is connected to the breadboard in the row of the 47Ω resistor through the bare end red wire and alligator clipped red wire.

pageData.altText: Figure 18: breadboard and DMM described in Figure 17 and Step 4

pageData.text: Turn on the DMM to 20m range in DCA, and record the current in Data Table 2. Turn off the DMM, and disconnect from the circuit. Disconnect the red wire of the rightmost battery from the breadboard.

Insert the black wire from the leftmost battery into the breadboard in the same row as the 47Ω resistor. Using the alligator clipped wires and 1 bare black wire, connect the DMM to this circuit in series at the point in the circuit highlighted in a red circle (see Figure19). You will be measuring the current in the right loop now. In this arrangement, the black DMM probe will be clipped to a black bare end wire and inserted in the same row as the 150Ω resistor and the red probe of the DMM is connected to the right battery’s red wire via an alligator clipped wire.

pageData.altText: Figure 19: Figure 16 schematic with the lower right corner circled in red

pageData.text: Turn on the DMM to 20m range in DCA, and record the current in Data Table 2. Turn off the DMM, and disconnect from the circuit. Disconnect the black wire of the left battery from the breadboard.
Finally, measure the current through the circuit’s bridge, the 82Ω resistor. Disconnect the lower wire of the 82Ω resistor from the breadboard.
Insert the left battery’s black wire into the same row with the 47Ω resistor’s end.
Insert the right battery’s red wire into the same row with the 150Ω resistor’s end.

Connect the DMM to this circuit in series at the point in the circuit highlighted in a red circle by connecting one end of the red alligator clip wire to the red DMM probe and the other end to the end of the resistor and the black alligator clip wire to the black DMM probe and the other end to the end of either the 47Ω or 150Ω resistor at their junction (see Figure 20). The setup should look like Figure 21.

pageData.altText: Figure 20: Figure 16 schematic with the lower center bridge circled in red
Figure 21: breadboard and DMM described in Figure 20 and Step 11

pageData.text: Turn on the DMM to 20m range in DCA, and record the current in Data Table 2. Turn off the DMM, and disconnect from the circuit. Disconnect the batteries from the circuit, and remove all resistors from the breadboard.
Using the current data and the voltage of the batteries, calculate the voltage drop across each resistor in the circuit and include in Data Table 3.

Using the methods used in Activities A and B, create two circuits of your own design. One should use 1 battery and 4 resistors in a combination of series and parallel. The other should use both batteries and four resistors. In that circuit, there should be two distinct loops with one battery in each loop.
Draw the schematic of each circuit.
For the first circuit, measure the current through each resistor in parallel and the circuit as a whole. Include these values in your schematic drawing.
For the second circuit, measure the current in each loop and the bridge, if applicable. Include these values in your schematic drawing.

Using the schematic circuits you drew in Step 2, use Kirchhoff's equations to prove that these values are true using the measured resistance for each resistor from Activity A and the currents in this activity.  Then photograph your circuits and equations and upload them to the Lab Notebook.

text: Using this circuit, calculate the current in the left loop, right loop, and the bridge section.

pageData.altText: A circuit schematic made up of a left loop and a right loop. In the left loop, from the positive end to the negative end of the +1.5-volt capacitor, the circuit is connected to a 4-ohm resistor and a 6-ohm resistor. In the right loop, from the positive end to the negative end of the +3-volt capacitor, the circuit is connected to the same 6-ohm resistor as the left loop and a 3-ohm resistor.

text: Using Kirchhoff’s rules, determine the voltage for the unknown voltage, V, and all the currents in the loops.

pageData.altText: A circuit schematic made up of a left loop and a right loop. In the left loop, the top edge has a +1-volt capacitor, and the outside edge of the loop on the positive side of the capacitor is a 5-ohm resistor. In the right loop, the outside edge of the loop has a +1.2-volt capacitor, and the top edge, on the positive side of the capacitor, has a 4-ohm resistor, while the bottom edge has a 1-ohm resistor. The shared edge on the inside of the loops has a 2-ohm resistor near the top edge and a capacitor labeled V near the bottom edge, with the positive end closest to the bottom edge. An arrow along the shared edge points to the bottom edge and is labeled 50 mA.

pageData.content: Experimental Design Diagram
pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow of this investigation. In Activity 1, you will measure the resistance of the resistors. Then, you will build the diagramed circuit and measure the current. Next, you will add additional resistors in series and measure the total resistance and current. Once you have added all of the circuits, you will graph current versus 1 over resistance. Then, you will build the new diagramed circuit, attach the multimeter in series at the specified location and measure the current in the circuit at the given locations.  Next, you will disconnect the multimeter. Once you have tested all of the locations, disconnect the circuit. Then, you will design and build your own circuit with the given parameters. Next, you will draw a schematic of the circuit and photograph it. Then, you will measure the current at the specified locations. Finally, once you have tested both circuits, you will evaluate them using Kirchoff’s equations.

data.title: Capacitor
data.content: A device used to store an electric charge; it consists of one or more pairs of conductors separated by an insulator

data.title: Current (I)
data.content: The magnitude of the moving charge carriers in a circuit

data.title: Digital multimeter (DMM)
data.content: A device used to measure two or more electrical values - principally voltage, current, and resistance

data.title: Electromotive force (emf)
data.content: The electric potential produced by either electrochemical cell or by changing the magnetic field

data.title: Kirchhoff's current Law
data.content: States that the current flowing into a junction must equal the current flowing out of a junction

data.title: Kirchhoff's voltage law
data.content: States that the sum of the electrical potential differences around any closed loop in a circuit is zero

data.title: Ohm's law
data.content: A law stating the relationship between voltage, current and resistance in a circuit

data.title: Potential (V)
data.content: The amount of work needed to move a unit charge from a reference point to a specific point against an electric field

data.title: Resistance (R)
data.content: A material's opposition to the movement of charge carriers

data.title: Resistor
data.content: An electronic device used to reduce voltage in a circuit by converting the electrical energy to heat

data.title: Transistor
data.content: A semiconductor device with three connections that is capable of amplification in addition to rectification
